content: The 1988 Winter Olympics, held in Calgary, Canada had a significant impact on the economy of the hosting country. The event generated approximately $1 billion in revenue, and created over 17,000 jobs in the lead up to, and during the games. The construction and renovation of sporting infrastructure, such as the Olympic Saddledome, helped to boost the local construction industry. Additionally, the influx of tourists into Calgary, the increase in trade and investment opportunities, and the international exposure that the games provided, helped to stimulate the local economy in the long-term. The legacy of the 1988 Winter Olympics continues to benefit the Canadian economy through increased tourism, improved infrastructure, and ongoing investment in sports and recreational facilities.
